Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diffusion of foreign particles in complex fluids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Complex fluids are seen everywhere in everyday life. They appear in industrial applications in the production of food products, cosmetics and advanced materials; and they occur naturally as biological fluids like mucus, blood and biofilms. Complex fluids are known to exhibit exotic properties, sometimes acting like solids, while at other times flowing freely like liquids. These are macroscale observations, but recent advances in particle tracking techniques have shed light on fascinating dynamics that occur at the microscale as well. Accurately characterizing and understanding the behavior of foreign particles in complex fluids is vital for certain applications. For example, learning why some particles penetrate biological fluids, while others do not, can be critical for the development of successful drug delivery techniques. Furthermore, it has been shown that the statistics of immersed particle paths can carry the signature of important large scale material properties, making it possible to study expensive complex fluids with microliter sized samples.

While there has been success in describing the motion of individual particles in complex fluids, developing models for interacting particle populations has proven frustrating for theoreticians. It is remarkable, for example, that there is no mathematical model for particles that individually behave according to fractional Brownian motion, but when close together, interact with each other through forces mediated by the laws of a fluid environment. This collaborative project addresses stochastic, numerical, and experimental issues arising in the study of diffusion of foreign particles in complex fluids. Specifically, we will consider two fluid models that amplify the fundamental relationships between mechanical properties of the fluids and particles paths. The models are (1) a linear viscoelastic fluid and (2) a motile suspension in a viscous fluid. In addition to developing the mathematical tools to efficiently and accurately simulate these models, we will use these simulations to address fundamental theoretical challenges that confront engineers who use particle tracking techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The movement of microparticles in viscoelastic fluids (like mucus, saliva, or a cell's cytoplasm), is very different from what is observed in viscous fluids (like water or molasses). In the latter case, how a particle behaves at one time is largely unaffected by what it has done in the past. Many viscoelastic fluids can be thought of as viscous fluids with tiny elastic structures immersed throughout. As a result, when a particle moves in a given direction, the environment goes with it to an extent, but then there is a restorative force against the particle. Its past affects its present. These persistent restorative forces have profound consequences for both the fluid?s properties and the movement patterns of the particles moving within them.  It has been shown by theoreticians and experimentalists that this has implications for a wide variety of applications, particularly when studying how foreign agents like viruses and medicinal nanoparticles move throughout the human body.

The work we did in this project consists of both ?forward? and ?inverse? problems. In forward problems we investigate predictions for how a particular particle or viscoelastic fluid might behave. For inverse problems, the challenge is to look at data collected by experimentalists and try to learn fluid and particle properties based on short videos of microparticle movement.  The challenge is that these videos are of a few individuals and they only last for a matter seconds or minutes, but biologically relevant questions involve millions of particles over hours or days. We addressed these connections from theory to data to extrapolation link-by-link. 

In terms of understanding the behavior of individual particles we used a mathematical model called the Generalized Langevin Equation (GLE) to describe microparticle motion in viscoelastic fluids. There are actually multiple mathematical models that theoreticians have proposed for particle motion, so one of our first efforts was the difficult statistical problem of determining whether the GLE really is a good choice for model. In our highest cited paper, we collaborated with statisticians and an experimentalist to show how to make such an assessment and to show that yes, indeed, the GLE is a good choice for studying how microparticles move in human mucus.

Why is it important to make sure we have the best possible model? It is because each of the candidate models make different predictions when it comes to long-term problems of interest. For one example, it has been known for a long time how long it should take, on average, for a particle in a viscous fluid to travel a given distance. This gives us understanding for how long it takes fluids to mix, or for a population of particles to diffuse through a layer of water.  But if we wish to know how long it will take for a virus particle, or a medicinal nanoparticle, to traverse a mucosal layer in the lungs, the viscous theory does not apply.  Working with graduate students and undergraduates at our respective institutions, we explored this ?first-passage problem? for viscoelastic diffusion and also how a particle?s memory of past motions shapes its long-term progress, and how particles in viscoelastic fluids respond when external forces are applied to them. We used both theoretical and computational techniques, proving theorems when possible.

An essential insight that motivated this entire field of research is that identical particles can behave very differently in different fluids. In our two jointly-authored papers we developed a forward and an inverse problem for understanding fluid-particle interactions. In the first of these, we thought of the particle as a passive passenger that simply follows the currents of the fluctuating fluid environment. Building on a similar existing method for viscous fluids, we showed how to build fluid simulations that yield realistic immersed particle behavior. For the inverse problem project, we examined a well-established protocol in the engineering literature for how to infer certain fluid properties from immersed particle behavior. While we found that certain mathematical assumptions underpinning the protocol were not valid, we nevertheless were able to put essential aspects on solid mathematical footing and moreover quantify various sources of uncertainty in learning fluid properties from particle behavior.

In total, eight papers were published during the award period, with another in review at the time of this report. Funds from this award were used to support five undergraduate research projects and one graduate student dissertation. There were special topics courses taught at each institution based on topics related to this research.
